Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: COUPLED HYDROLOGICAL AND GEOCHEMICAL PROCESS EVOLUTION AT THE LANDSCAPE EVOLUTION OBSERVATORY
Award.AbstractNarration:
The physical, chemical and biological structures and processes controlling biogeochemical reaction, flow and transport in natural landscapes interact at multiple space and time scales and are difficult to quantify. The current paradigm of hydrological and biogeochemical theory is that process descriptions derived from observations at small scales can be applied to predict at much larger scales, as long as some effective values of the scale dependent parameters can be identified. However, this paradigm is known to be flawed and increasingly frequent calls have been made for new theories that will better link small-scale process understanding with large-scale predictions. Furthermore, natural systems evolve in time in a way that is hard to observe in short-run laboratory experiments or in natural landscapes with unknown initial conditions and time-variant forcing. This project will use carefully designed wetting and drying experiments using stable water isotope tracers at the hillslope scale to determine the structure of flow paths, as well as to quantify water transit time distributions along those flow paths. Chemical analysis of pore waters and hillslope outflow will determine mineral weathering kinetics during these wetting-drying cycles which will be related to observed water transit times. Detailed numerical modeling with a coupled systems model will be used to simulate the flow and reactive transport and the evolution of the porous medium through data assimilation and inverse modeling.

This project will observe the way water, rock and life interact and create the organized structure of the soil. These observations will be made at an unprecedented spatial and temporal resolution using the Landscape Evolution Observatory (LEO) at Biosphere 2. LEO consists of three large artificial landscapes built in a climate controlled environment that contain over 1,800 sensors to measure how water flows through these landscapes and interacts with the soil minerals and microbiological ecosystems. The research outcome will contribute to a new generation of modeling tools for quantifying contaminant transport in a changing environment. The result will reconcile the discrepancies between observations of flow and transport phenomena at lab and field scales. Two PhD students and several undergraduate students will be trained in novel hydrologic-geochemical experimentation and Earth systems modeling, and their research will be shared with the 100,000 people that visit Biosphere 2 each year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central aim of this project has been to develop a new understanding of the way material dissolved in water is transported with that water through the landscape. There is a pressing need for models that can make predictions about this to help us understand our water resources, the threats to them from non-point-source contamination, and the best approaches for mitigating those threats.

The best methods available to making such predictions at fine scales (like contaminated sites) are not as useful when applied at larger scales (like large watersheds). New approaches have been developed though, based on the concept of StorAge Selection (SAS) functions. SAS functions are based on mass-balance principles and capture the essential features of transport at the landscape scale, and require much less data and computation power compared to other methods. However it was not clear how to determine what the SAS function should look like for any given landscape.

This project aimed to address this problem using the extraordinary experimental facilities available at the Landscape Evolution Observatory (LEO) at Biosphere2: three artificial hillslopes (11m x 30 m) embedded with thousands of sensors for observing the movement of water and solutes. PI Harman developed an experimental procedure, called PERTH (the PERiodic Tracer Hierarchy) that would allow researchers to make direct measurements of the SAS function for these hillslopes. That method required applying precisely controlled amounts of artificial rainfall to the hillslopes twice a week for two months. Some of the rain was labeled using salt and water that contained non-radioactive heavy isotopes of hydrogen. By observing the release of these labels in the outflow from the hillslope, the SAS function could be observed.

The project proceeded in stages, first applying the PERTH method to a small prototype hillslope, the miniLEO. This experiment produced exciting results, published in two papers. They showed that the SAS functions were mostly related to the saturated part of the storage in the miniLEO. The results also helped refine the plan for the PERTH experiment on the full LEO hillslopes.

Those were conducted in Nov-Dec 2016. The breakthrough curves from the full LEO experiments showed complex fluctuating behavior that could not be reproduced by the existing methods for making predictions about transport at landscape scales. Using the PERTH method, these curves could be directly converted into time-varying TTD, from which each hillslope’s SAS function was be recovered.

The results showed that the complex variability of the breakthrough curves could be decomposed into two components, for which they coined the termsexternaland internalvariability. Only the latter is associated with changes in the structure of flow through the system and changes in the shape of the SAS function. The former refers to the variability induced by the time varying fluxes through the system, which inevitably produce time-varying rates of transport even when the flow pathways through the system (and SAS function) don’t change.

The PERTH experiment on LEO yielded a wealth of data that will continue to be mined for some time to come. The results demonstrated that the LEO hillslopes have some fundamentally different transport properties from the miniLEO. In particular, the effect of the time-delay associated with lateral flow and the unsaturated zone is much more pronounced in the LEO hillslope as compared to the miniLEO. The researchers were able to demonstrate that this is primarily due to the difference in basic geometrical features of the two system – in particular the aspect ratio of the aquifer and the slope of the underlying surface.

The results form the artificial hillslopes helped the researchers develop a theory that relates the shape of SAS functions to the properties of real landscapes. The theory explains the physical origins of SAS functions, and successfully reproduces the results of the LEO and miniLEO experiments. 

The work supported by this grant has begun to have a major impact on the discipline, and papers published through the grant have been highly cited. A number of collaborations have arisen, including ones to take this new knowledge and apply it to real landscapes. This new knowledge will soon have an impact on the way we make predictions of the transport of water and contaminants through the landscape.

This grant has also helped promote science within the broader community. The Biosphere 2 facility receives 100,000 visitors each year, and has education and outreach programs that are sustainable and community-oriented. During public tours, the interpretive specialists at B2 provide background information about all the research being conducted at B2, including this project. At special events throughout the year, the team at LEO works with students at all levels to enhance their interest in STEM disciplines. This undoubtedly contributes positively to raising the number of young people that will get an education in STEM fields, and thus contributes significantly to society.
